dog saved my life if it wasn't for him
did Phil de was abducted and forcibly
recruited into the rebel army in
northern Uganda when she was 13 she
witnessed some of the worst atrocities
and saw her brothers tortured and killed
in front of her by the time she managed
to escape she was suicidal and suffering
from PTSD when I came back home I had
terrible nightmares about how my
brothers were killed and the terrible
things that happen to me in captivity
but the people in the village taunted me
and spoke badly about me they called me
a murderer and said I was cursed by the
spirits she was given her dog by the
comfort of project the NGO helps
transform the region's stray and
unwanted dogs into healing therapy
animals for former child soldiers and
survivors of war struggling with PTSD
trauma and depression Yana where right
now Aloha Rama his name is Laura it
means no more person your words can't
hurt a dog that has suffered should be
able to help someone who has gone
through trauma Francis was blinded by a
bomb blast in his village when he was 12
years old he realized the healing
potential of dogs when two of them
gradually befriended him and began
guiding him to and from school I felt
dogs can help people rehabilitate their
psychological conditions so that they
have the company gain confidence and
also overcome depression he trained as a
psychologist and set up the comfort dog
project in 2015 to help people recover
from mental health conditions
during the 5-month therapy program the
comfortable Guardians learn to train and
care for their dogs the group also
undergoes extensive trauma counseling to
help them process their past experiences
and they are Granma nath when they give
me local Roma they started teaching me
about how to control my anger and how to
deal with my emotions so when I feel
that moment of rage I call him next to
me start rubbing his back and then I
feel better I just focus on him but it's
still a challenge for the project to
gain acceptance in northern Uganda
people use dogs for hunting guiding
homes and also they look at dogs as
useless and even though Uganda's
Ministry of Health estimates about 70
percent of people in northern Uganda
have been dramatically affected by the
war there's still stigma around mental
health services people think the moment
you go to mental health
you are already mentally disoriented you
cannot be helped but attitudes in the
community are starting to change as part
of her recovery filter assists with
veterinary outreach and educates people
on dog training animal rights and
welfare when I begin to talk and local
remains nearly it gives me the strength
and courage to start talking
I really had a difficult life but with
no piranhas now that has changed it's
easy
